title: US Military Launches Strikes at Iran Linked Targets in Syria
description: The US launched strikes on facilities in eastern Syria used by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps and Iran-affiliated groups on Sunday.

title: US Shutdown Risk Lingers Despite House Speaker’s Compromise Plan
description: The US still faces a risk of a government shutdown at the end of this week despite a new compromise plan by Speaker Mike Johnson that leaves out hardline conservative priorities like cutting spending and curtailing migration.

title: Major LA Freeway Faces Long-Term Closures After Fire, Mayor Says
description: A stretch of a major freeway near downtown Los Angeles will be closed indefinitely after a fire beneath the roadway destroyed infrastructure last week.

title: Adams Probe Includes Questions Into Turkish Consulate Project: NYT
description: The growing federal investigation into New York City Mayor Eric Adams’s campaign now includes questions into whether he used his influence with the Fire Department to help Turkey move into a new consulate building despite safety concerns, the New York Times reported Sunday.

title: GOP’s McDaniel Defends Party on Abortion After Election Losses
description: Republican National Committee Chairwoman Ronna McDaniel took aim at critics within her party following last week’s disappointing off-year election results, saying the GOP needs to stop the “circular firing squad” and focus on beating President Joe Biden.

title: Resumed US-China Military Talks Are Priority for Biden-Xi Summit
description: Presidents Joe Biden and Xi Jinping will discuss reestablishing US-China military communications at their summit this week, US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan said.

title: Sunak’s Foreign Policy Speech, Rwanda Ruling: Sunday UK Briefing
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak lays out his foreign policy vision, the UK’s high court rules on his controversial immigration policy, a slew of economic data may give clues on the health of the economy and the home secretary’s job hangs in the balance. Here’s a look at what’s happening this week.The big speech: Sunak outlines his foreign policy goals Monday night at the Lord Mayor’s Banquet in London. Between Ukraine, Israel, China and the Conservative Party’s own immigration policies there’s plenty

title: South Africa Unveils Proposals for Major Immigration Overhaul
description: South Africa unveiled proposals aimed at overhauling and simplifying laws governing citizenship, immigration and refugee protection.

title: Spanish Protests Against Deal With Catalans Escalate in Madrid
description: Tens of thousands of people gathered in central Madrid to protest against acting Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez‘s plans to grant amnesty to hundreds of Catalan separatists involved in a failed bid for independence.

title: Eskom Ramps Up Power Cuts as it Releases Schedule for the Week
description: South Africa’s state-owned utility Eskom Holdings SOC said it will implement so-called stage 1 power cuts — removing 1,000 megawatts from the grid — from 4 p.m. Sunday until 5 a.m. on Monday.

title: South Africa’s ‘Too White’ Farms May Lose EU, UK Access
description: South African farms deemed “too white” will no longer be able to export their produce to the UK and the EU, according to postings in the Government Gazette, the Johannesburg-based City Press newspaper reported.

title: Violence at London March Puts Spotlight on Sunak’s Leadership
description: Clashes between police and mainly far-right counter-protesters at a pro-Palestinian march in London have put the spotlight back on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak after a week of political tension over comments by a senior member of his UK government.

title: War Budget Leaves Netanyahu Caught Between Markets and Politics
description: With Israel’s war against Hamas costing the economy around $260 million every day, payouts to ultra-orthodox schools and other causes championed by right-wingers in the ruling coalition have set off a reckoning for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Ukraine Recap: Officer Linked in Reports to Nord Stream Sabotage
description: A senior Ukrainian military officer with deep ties to the country’s intelligence services played a central role in sabotaging the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in 2022, the Washington Post and Germany’s Der Spiegel reported, citing officials in Ukraine and elsewhere who weren’t identified.

title: What Happens If the Government Loses on Rwanda?: Q&A
description: The UK’s controversial flagship immigration policy faces its sternest test this week, when the nation’s top court will decide whether it’s lawful.

title: Inside the Philippines’ Dangerous Mission in the South China Sea
description: As sailors scrambled to unload provisions from two small boats for troops on a grounded ship in the South China Sea, a US Navy aircraft flew overhead while three Japanese-built Philippine coast guard vessels kept watch.

title: Israel Latest: Fighting Surrounds Hospitals as Cease-Fire Urged
description: Israel vowed to press on with military operations in Gaza, as France added to rising international calls for a cease-fire. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed the idea of the Palestinian Authority returning to govern the territory.

title: Sadiq Khan Joins Calls for Rishi Sunak to Sack Suella Braverman
description: Mayor of London Sadiq Khan has followed Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer in calling for Rishi Sunak to sack Home Secretary Suella Braverman for stoking tensions ahead of Armistice Day.

title: Labour to Put Plans for Stronger Budget Watchdog to Commons Vote
description: Labour is set to put its plans to strengthen the budget watchdog to a vote in Parliament in an effort to "prevent a repeat of Liz Truss's disastrous mini-budget", Rachel Reeves has said.

title: Portugal’s Outgoing Premier Apologizes for Cash in Aide’s Office
description: Portugal’s Antonio Costa, who unexpectedly resigned as prime minister on Tuesday amid a probe into possible government corruption, apologized on television for envelopes of cash seized in his chief of staff’s office as part of the ongoing investigation.
